# I4CS 2025: Call for Papers

The **25th International Conference on Innovations for Community Services (I4CS)** will take place from **June 11 - 13, 2025, in Munich, Germany**. This year's conference celebrates a quarter-century of advancements under the motto **"Celebrating I4CS' Quarter-Century."**

I4CS serves as a vibrant hub for researchers, practitioners, and stakeholders to explore cutting-edge developments in computer science and their profound potential to enrich community services. The conference program features engaging presentations, thought-provoking panel discussions, and hands-on workshops, all designed to investigate the convergence of technology, applications, and community.

## Topics of Interest

The conference addresses internet community systems, foundations, technology, applications, and socializations. Topics include, but are not limited to original work in the following areas:

### Technology: Emerging Architectures and Frameworks
*   Data architectures and enablers for community services
*   Cryptography and cryptology
*   5G/6G technologies and ad-hoc wireless networks
*   Data models, analytics, and big data management
*   Quantum and cloud computing

### Applications: Smart Communities on the Move
*   Social networks, open data, and distributed coworking
*   Barrier-free collaboration, publishing, and eLearning
*   Recommender solutions and chat bots
*   Virtual & augmented reality, robotics, and mobile e-sports
*   Intelligent traffic, logistics, and connected cars

### Socialization: Ambient Work and Living
*   Distributed work challenges and eHealth-assisted living
*   Machine Learning, human-centered AI, and governance
*   Smart home, energy control, and public infrastructure
*   Internet of things and dynamic sensor networks
*   Cyber- and information security

## Important Dates

*   **Paper submission (extended):** February 23, 2025
*   **Authors' notification:** March 23, 2025
*   **Camera-ready copies:** March 30, 2025
*   **Presenters' registration:** March 30, 2025
*   **Conference:** June 11 - 13, 2025

## Submission and Publication

I4CS solicits submissions of unpublished papers presenting research results, industrial experiences, applications, and open problems.

*   **Submission Format:** Electronic submission is required. Full papers of no more than **20 pages** and written in American English should be submitted as PDF files.
*   **Submission System:** Please submit using the EasyChair conference management system: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=i4cs2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=i4cs2025).
*   **Review Process:** All submitted papers will be subject to a single-blind review process by at least three members of the program committee. Anonymizing submissions is not necessary.
*   **Publication:** I4CS Proceedings will be published with Springer in the "Communications in Computer and Information Science" (CCIS) series. Papers will be submitted to indexing libraries, e.g., DBLP, Scopus, and for consideration by the Web of Science (WoS) conference proceedings citation index.
*   **Formatting Instructions:** Refer to [https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines).

## Hosts and Supporters

*   **Hosted by:** LMU Munich, Germany
*   **Supported by:** Ernst-Abbe-Hochschule Jena, University of Applied Sciences; Deutsche Telekom AG, Group Technology

# IC3K 2025: Call for Papers

The International Joint Conference on Knowledge Discovery, Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management (IC3K) 2025 aims to bring together researchers, engineers, and practitioners in the areas of Knowledge Discovery, Knowledge Engineering, and Knowledge Management.

The conference is composed of three co-located conferences, each specializing in at least one of the main knowledge areas.

IC3K 2025 will be held in conjunction with ICINCO 2025, WEBIST 2025, IN4PL 2025, IJCCI 2025, and CoopIS 2025.

## Conference Areas

Conference areas will be available soon.

## Keynote Speakers

*   **Richard Chbeir**, Université de Pau et des Pays de l'Adour (UPPA), France
*   **Henry Prakken**, Utrecht University, Netherlands

## Paper Submission

Authors should submit a paper in English, carefully checked for correct grammar and spelling, addressing one or several of the conference areas or topics. Papers should clearly indicate the nature of their technical/scientific contribution, and the problems, domains or environments to which it is applicable.

**Double-blind paper evaluation method:** Authors are kindly requested to produce and provide the paper WITHOUT any reference to any of the authors, including the authors’ personal details, the acknowledgments section of the paper, and any other reference that may disclose the authors’ identity.

Only original papers should be submitted. Authors are advised to read INSTICC's ethical norms regarding plagiarism and self-plagiarism thoroughly before submitting and must make sure that their submissions do not substantially overlap work which has been published elsewhere or simultaneously submitted to a journal or another conference with proceedings. Papers that contain any form of plagiarism will be rejected without reviews.

Authors can submit their work in the form of a **Regular Paper** (completed and validated research) or as a **Position Paper** (short report of work in progress or an arguable opinion about an issue).

All papers must be submitted through the online submission platform PRIMORIS and should follow the instructions and templates found under Guidelines and Templates.

## Publications

All accepted papers will be published in the conference proceedings, under an ISBN reference, on paper and on digital support.

*   SCITEPRESS is a member of CrossRef and every paper on our digital library is given a DOI (Digital Object Identifier).
*   The proceedings will be submitted for indexation by SCOPUS, Google Scholar, DBLP, Semantic Scholar, EI and Web of Science / Conference Proceedings Citation Index.

A short list of best papers will be invited for a post-conference special issue of the Springer Nature Computer Science Journal.

It is planned to publish a short list of revised and extended versions of presented papers with Springer in a CCIS Series book.

All dates refer to AOE time, i.e. "Anywhere on Earth".

# Call for Papers: IEEE Workshop on High Performance Switching and Routing (HPSR 2025)

## Conference Overview

The 26th IEEE International Conference on High Performance Switching and Routing (HPSR 2025) will be held from **May 20 to 22, 2025**, in **Suita, Osaka, Japan**.

HPSR serves as a foundational technology in high-speed data networks, enabling the growth of telecommunications, Internet services, and enterprise networks. It has been crucial in supporting evolving paradigms such as network virtualization, cloud-edge computing, green networking, and the Internet of Things. In the current AI-centric era, scalable, low-latency, and fault-tolerant switching and routing solutions are more essential than ever, especially for data center networks supporting AI workloads.

HPSR 2025 will feature six technical paper sessions, four workshops exploring emerging themes, three tutorials on key technologies, outstanding keynote speakers, a poster session for early-stage work, and a panel session.

## Submission Topics

We are seeking original and thought-provoking works on switching, routing, and networking and their applied technologies. Submissions on autonomous networks, 5G/6G, IoT, Industry 4.0, cybersecurity, virtualization, and other advanced topics, including AI/ML for communications and networking, are encouraged. ### High-Performance Functionality and Architectures:

# Call for Papers: ICAPS 2025

The International Conference on Automated Planning and Scheduling (ICAPS) is the premier forum for exchanging news and research results on the theory and applications of intelligent and automated planning and scheduling technology.

ICAPS 2025, the 35th edition of the conference series, will take place in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia, from **November 9-14, 2025**. The conference is co-located with KR-2025, CPAIOR-2025, and the Planning and Optimisation Summer School 2025.

## Types of Submissions

ICAPS 2025 invites paper submissions on all aspects of automated planning and scheduling. Contributions are welcome in the following categories:

*   **Theoretical papers:** Focusing on analytical tools, complexity results, expressiveness, and new theoretical frameworks.
*   **Algorithmic papers:** Describing novel perspectives and substantial improvements for solving planning and scheduling problems.
*   **Modelling papers:** Detailing new representations of planning and scheduling problems and their solutions.
*   **Position papers:** Offering critiques or new perspectives on the field, meta-analyses, or challenge problems.
*   **Tools papers:** Describing useful systems built with novel algorithmic and engineering techniques, such as integrated planning systems, model checkers, libraries, or benchmarking tools.

All submissions must be classified by high-level topics and subject-matter keywords, available from the [ICAPS 2025 homepage](/organisation/paper_classification_system).

## Key Dates

All deadlines are in UTC-12 (Anywhere on Earth).

*   **Submission site opens:** October 1, 2024
*   **Abstracts due:** October 25, 2024
*   **Full papers due:** November 1, 2024
*   **Desk reject notification:** November 15, 2024
*   **Phase 1 author notification:** December 16, 2024
*   **Author feedback period:** January 27-31, 2025
*   **Phase 2 author notification:** February 28, 2025

## Author Guidelines

### Paper Length and Formatting

*   All paper types can be submitted as either **long (8 pages + 1 page of references)** or **short (4 pages + 1 page of references)**.
*   The paper length must be indicated at submission time. Over-length papers will be rejected without review.
*   All papers must adhere to the **AAAI 2025 author kit instructions** for formatting, available at [this link](/files/icaps2025-author-kit.zip).

### Review Process and Criteria

*   Papers will be reviewed based on relevance, originality, significance, clarity, and soundness.
*   Review process outcomes can be: acceptance for oral presentation, acceptance for poster presentation (non-archival), or rejection.
*   Submissions are expected to meet the high standards of publication expected by ICAPS.
*   Papers cannot be submitted to other conferences or journals during the ICAPS 2025 review period, nor be already under review, accepted, or published elsewhere.
*   Multiple submissions must have significant, unique content; papers with substantial overlap may be rejected.
*   The conference format will be **in-person**, requiring at least one author to present the work in person, unless exceptional circumstances prevent it.

### Use of Generative AI

*   Papers including text generated from LLMs are prohibited unless presented as part of the paper’s experimental analysis.
*   Using these technologies for editing or polishing author-written text is permitted.
*   AI systems cannot satisfy the criteria for authorship and cannot be used as citable sources.
*   Authors are fully responsible for the content, including checking for plagiarism and authenticity.

### Ethical / Societal Impact

*   Authors are encouraged to include a statement on the potential broader impact, ethical aspects, and societal consequences of their work.
*   This statement can be in the main body or reference page. Reviewers may request it during the author response period.

### Best Paper Awards and Journal Fast Track

*   Best non-student and student papers will be awarded.
*   Selected papers may receive an invitation to submit an extended version to journals like Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR) or Artificial Intelligence Journal (AIJ).

## Submission Instructions

### Platform

All submissions will be made electronically via [OpenReview](https://openreview.net/group?id=icaps-conference.org/ICAPS/2025/Conference).

### Anonymity and Double-Blind Requirements

*   Submissions must be anonymous for double-blind reviewing.
*   Omit author names and institutions.
*   Refer to prior work (self or others) in the third person.
*   Ensure acknowledgments or ethics statements do not reveal identities.
*   Posting manuscripts on repositories like Arxiv.org is discouraged during critical review windows.

### Supplementary Material

*   Authors can submit supplementary material (videos, proofs, results) alongside the PDF paper.
*   Supplementary material must be anonymized unless otherwise specified.
*   Papers should be self-contained; reviewers are encouraged but not obligated to consider supporting material.

### Compliance

Failure to comply with submission instructions will result in desk rejection.

## Program Chairs and Contact

*   **Chairs:** Daniel Harabor (Monash University, Australia), Miquel Ramirez (University of Melbourne, Australia)
*   **Email:** icaps25pc [at] googlegroups [dot] com

# IPEC 2025: Call for Papers

The 20th International Symposium on Parameterized and Exact Computation (IPEC 2025) invites papers presenting original research in the area of parameterized and exact algorithms and complexity.

IPEC 2025 is part of ALGO 2025, which also hosts ESA 2025 and other specialized conferences and workshops. The event is planned as an in-person conference.

## Topics

The topics include but are not limited to:

*   new techniques for the design and analysis of parameterized and exact algorithms;
*   fixed-parameter tractability and kernelization results;
*   parameterized complexity theory;
*   parameterized (in)approximability results;
*   relationships between parameterized complexity and traditional complexity classifications;
*   applications of parameterized and exact computation;
*   engineering and experimentation of exact, parameterized, and kernelization algorithms.

## Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions are required to be in the [LIPIcs format](https://drops.dagstuhl.de/entities/series/LIPIcs#author). No changes to font size, page margins, etc., are permitted. Line numbers must be activated.
*   Submissions of the full version of the paper are welcome. The first 12 pages (excluding the title page) should be sufficient for assessment and contain a summary of the main results, their motivation and importance, and evidence of their correctness.
*   Results previously published or under simultaneous submission will not be considered.
*   PC members (outside the PC chairs) are allowed to author or coauthor submissions.
*   **Double-blind reviewing:** IPEC 2025 employs a lightweight double-blind reviewing process. Submissions should not reveal the identity of the authors. Ensure that references to your own work are in the third person. Authors may post drafts online or submit to arXiv, and may mention the existence of publicly available versions without providing links.

## Conflicts of Interest

Authors are responsible for declaring conflicts of interest with any of the PC members, including family members, close friends, advisors/advisees, people with the same affiliation, and frequent collaborators.

## Submission Link

Submissions via EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ipec2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=ipec2025)

## Important Dates

*   **Abstract submission / paper registration:** June 27th (23:59 AoE)
*   **Submission deadline:** June 30th (23:59 AoE)
*   **Notification:** August 7th
*   **IPEC dates:** Sept. 17—19 (Wed-Fri)

## Conference and Paper Publication

Authors of accepted papers are expected to present their work at the symposium. The conference proceedings will be published in the Leibniz International Proceedings in Informatics (LIPIcs) series after the conference (post-proceedings).

## Awards

# ICAART 2026: Call for Papers

The International Conference on Agents and Artificial Intelligence (ICAART 2026) aims to bring together researchers, engineers, and practitioners interested in the theory and applications in the areas of Agents and Artificial Intelligence. The scientific goal is to stimulate the development of new ideas for further progress.

### Onsite and Online Options

To accommodate various situations, ICAART 2026 is offering the option for either physical presence at the venue or virtual participation (via PDF slides or pre-recorded videos).

### Co-located Events

ICAART 2026 will be held in conjunction with **MODELSWARD 2026**, **ICISSP 2026**, and **PHOTOPTICS 2026**. Registration for ICAART allows free access to these co-located conferences (as a non-speaker).

## Scope

On one side, the conference focuses on Agents, Multi-Agent Systems, Software Platforms, and Distributed Problem Solving. On the other side, it focuses on Artificial Intelligence, Knowledge Representation, Planning, Learning, Scheduling, and Perception. Applications using Natural Language Processing (NLP), Large Language Models (LLMs), Legal Technologies, and Quantum Computing are also highlighted.

Papers describing original work are invited in any of the areas listed below. Accepted papers, presented at the conference by one of the authors, will be published in the Proceedings of ICAART with an ISBN. Acceptance will be based on quality, relevance, and originality. Both full research reports and work-in-progress reports are welcome. There will be both oral and poster sessions.

Special sessions dedicated to case-studies and commercial presentations, as well as tutorials dedicated to technical/scientific topics, are also envisaged. Companies interested in presenting their products/methodologies or researchers interested in holding a tutorial, workshop, or special session are invited to contact the conference secretariat or visit the conference website.

## Conference Areas

The following list of sub-topics is not exhaustive. Papers may address one or more of the listed sub-topics, although authors should not feel limited by them. Unlisted but related sub-topics are also acceptable, provided they fit in one of the main topic areas.

### AREA 1: AGENTS

### AREA 2: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

*   Visualization

## Keynote Speakers

ICAART 2026 will feature several invited keynote speakers, who are internationally recognized experts in their areas. Their names are not yet confirmed.

## Submission Guidelines

Authors can submit their work as a **complete paper** (Regular Paper or Position Paper) or an **abstract**. Please note that accepted abstracts are presented but *not* published in the proceedings.

*   **Regular Papers** represent completed and validated research.
*   **Position Papers** portray a short report of work in progress or an arguable opinion about an issue.

All papers must be submitted in **English**, carefully checked for correct grammar and spelling, and address one or several of the conference areas or topics. Each paper should clearly indicate the nature of its technical/scientific contribution and its applicability.

### Double-Blind Review

To facilitate the double-blind paper evaluation method, authors are kindly requested to produce and provide the paper **WITHOUT any reference to any of the authors**, including personal details, acknowledgments, or any other reference that may disclose the authors’ identity.

### Plagiarism Policy

Only **original papers** should be submitted. Authors are advised to read INSTICC's ethical norms regarding plagiarism and self-plagiarism thoroughly. Submissions must not substantially overlap with work published elsewhere or simultaneously submitted to another journal or conference with proceedings. Papers containing any form of plagiarism will be rejected without reviews. Authors should also avoid using an excessive number of self-citations.

### Submission Platform and Formatting

All papers must be submitted through the online submission platform **PRIMORIS** and should follow the instructions and templates found under Guidelines and Templates (available via the conference website).

*   Only `.pdf` or `.doc` files will be accepted for paper submission.
*   Final author manuscripts will be **8.5" x 11"**, not exceeding **6 pages**; a maximum of **4 extra pages** is allowed at additional cost.
*   **LaTeX Template:** A community-provided LaTeX template (the CTAN package `iaria` or `iaria-lite`) and an Overleaf template example are available. Ensure adherence to additional editorial rules.
*   **MS Word Template:** Helpful information for paper formatting for MS Word is available.
*   Slides-based contributions can use corporate/university formats and styles.

### Contribution Types and Suggested Presentation Slides

*   **Regular Papers:** (up to 6-10 pages) - **12-14 presentation slides suggested.** These can be academic or industrial research, survey, white, implementation-oriented, architecture-oriented papers, etc. They will be included in the proceedings, posted in the free-access ThinkMind digital library, and sent for indexing.
*   **Short Papers (work in progress):** (up to 4 pages) - **12-14 presentation slides suggested.** These represent partial achievements of longer-term projects. They will be published in the conference proceedings, posted in the free-access ThinkMind digital library, and sent for indexing.
*   **Ideas Contributions:** (2 pages) - **12-14 presentation slides suggested.** Dedicated to new ideas in their very early stage for debate and audience feedback. Will be published in proceedings, ThinkMind digital library, and sent for indexing.
*   **Extended Abstracts:** (2 pages) - **12-14 presentation slides suggested.** Summarize potential long publications with noticeable results, intended for sharing or future journal publication. Will be published in proceedings, ThinkMind digital library, and sent for indexing.
*   **Posters (Paper-based):** (2 pages) - **8-10 presentation slides suggested.** Intended for ongoing research, concrete realizations, or industrial applications/projects. The paper will be published in proceedings, ThinkMind digital library, and sent for indexing. A physical poster is also suitable for live discussions.
*   **Posters (Slide-based, only):** (8-10 slide-deck) - **8-10 presentation slides suggested.** For ongoing projects, realizations, or industrial presentations. The slide-deck will be posted post-event on [www.iaria.org](http://www.iaria.org/). A physical poster is also suitable.
*   **Presentations (Slide-based, only):** (12-14 slide-deck) - **12-14 presentation slides suggested.** These are technical marketing/industrial/business/positioning presentations. The slide-deck will be posted post-event on [www.iaria.org](http://www.iaria.org/).

# Call for Papers: ICAIIC 2026

The 8th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Information and Communication (ICAIIC 2026) aims to facilitate the transfer of AI technologies into practical applications, developing intelligent ICT systems, and exploring AI applications for content, platforms, networks, and devices.

The conference will take place in **Tokyo, Japan & as a Virtual Conference**.

ICAIIC 2026 invites original, unpublished contributions in all aspects of AI in information and communication. Submitted articles must not be under consideration for publication elsewhere. The conference also welcomes submissions of short papers on early-stage research or development in progress, position papers on new ideas, and industry papers.

## Publication

Accepted and presented papers will be published in the **ICAIIC Conference Proceedings** with an assigned ISBN number and submitted to IEEE Xplore, Scopus, and EI Compendex. Additionally, extended versions of selected papers will be published in international journals as a special issue for ICAIIC 2026, including:

*   **ICT Express (SCIE)**
*   **Wireless Personal Communications (SCIE)**
*   **Wireless Communications and Mobile Computing (SCIE)**

## Topics of Interest

The topics include, but are not limited to:

*   Information and Communications Technology
*   AI for Image Processing and Multimedia
*   AI Applications for Networking and IoT
*   AI for Control and Decision Systems
*   AI Applications for Mobile Communication
*   AI for Energy, Computer Systems and Semiconductor Device
*   AI for Data Analysis, Big Data and Cloud
*   AI for Neuroscience and Neuroengineering
*   AI for eHealth
*   AI for Industrial Applications
*   AI Mobility
*   AI for Security and Privacy in Blockchain
*   AI for Services Applications and Emerging Topics
*   AI Foundation

## Submission Guidelines

*   **Format:** All papers must be submitted electronically in **PDF format** via EDAS.
*   **Link:** [https://edas.info/N32555](https://edas.info/N32555)
*   **Formatting:** Submissions should be formatted with single-spaced, double-column pages using at least **10-point font** on A4 or letter-sized pages in IEEE style.
*   **Length:** The maximum length for full papers is **6 pages**. Full papers must be at least 3 pages long.
*   Detailed formatting and submission instructions will be available on the conference website.

## Call for Workshop Proposals

Proposals are invited for half-day or full-day workshops on communication and networking topics. Please contact the chairs, Sungrae Cho and Howon Kim, at [srcho@cau.ac.kr](mailto:srcho@cau.ac.kr) and [howonkim@pusan.ac.kr](mailto:howonkim@pusan.ac.kr).

## Best Paper Awards

The best papers will be selected by the technical program committee members from among the regular papers presented at ICAIIC 2026.

*   **Camera-Ready Paper:** Dec. 15, 2025

## Committees

*   **International Advisory Committee**

# ICCC'25: Call for Papers

Welcome to the **16th International Conference on Computational Creativity (ICCC'25)**, taking place from **June 23rd to June 27th, 2025**, in **Campinas, Brazil**.

Computational creativity is a discipline with roots in Artificial Intelligence, Cognitive Science, Engineering, Design, Psychology, and Philosophy, exploring the potential for computers to be creative—either in partnership with humans or as autonomous creators.

## About the Conference

ICCC is the only scientific conference that focuses exclusively on computational creativity and covers all aspects of the field. The conference series has been organized by the Association for Computational Creativity since 2010.

## Contribution Types & Presentation

We welcome the submission of five different types of full papers:

*   **Technical papers:** Emphasis on solid experimentation, computational models, formal proof, and/or argumentation demonstrating advancement. Strong evaluation is essential.
*   **System or Resource description papers:** Focus on building and deploying creative systems or resources. Emphasis on engineering achievement, technical difficulties, techniques employed, and reusable resources.
*   **Study papers:** Draw on allied fields (psychology, philosophy, etc.) or appeal to broader AI/Computer Science areas. Emphasis on novel perspectives related to building, assessing, or deploying CC systems.
*   **Cultural application papers:** Present the use of creative software in a cultural setting (e.g., art exhibitions, concerts, literature). Emphasis on the system's role, results, technical details, and evaluative feedback.
*   **Position papers:** Present opinions on aspects of CC research culture, future directions, or current issues. Emphasis on carefully arguing a position and providing thought leadership.

All submissions will be evaluated based on their scientific, technical, artistic, and/or cultural contribution. The program committee will decide the best format for presenting accepted manuscripts. At least one author must present the paper live at the conference.

*   **Full Papers:** Prepare slides for a 15-minute talk, followed by 10 minutes for questions/discussion.
*   **Short Papers (with oral presentation):** Prepare slides for an 8-minute talk, followed by Q&A.

## Important Dates

All deadlines are 23:59 Anywhere on Earth (AoE) time.

*   **Abstracts due:** [February 14, 2025] [February 21, 2025]
*   **Submissions due (Full Papers):** [February 21, 2025] [February 28, 2025]
*   **Acceptance notification (Full Papers):** [April 11, 2025]
*   **Submissions due (Short Papers):** [April 21, 2025] [April 25, 2025]
*   **Acceptance notification (Short Papers):** [May 7, 2025] [May 13, 2025]
*   **Camera-ready copies due (Full Papers):** [May 2, 2025] [May 9, 2025]
*   **Camera-ready copies due (Short Papers):** [May 14, 2025] [May 19, 2025]
*   **Conference:** June 23–27, 2025

## Themes and Topics

Original research contributions are solicited in all areas related to Computational Creativity research and practice, including, but not limited to:

*   **Applications of Computational Creativity:** Music, language, games, visual arts, design, architecture, entertainment, education, mathematical invention, scientific discovery, programming.
*   **Human-Machine Co-Creativity:** Systems, studies, frameworks, or methodologies for co-creativity between humans and AI.
*   **Computational Creativity Evaluation:** Metrics, frameworks, formalisms, and methodologies for evaluating creativity in computational systems.
*   **Social Models:** Computational models of social aspects of creativity, including social creativity, diffusion of ideas, collaboration, and team dynamics.
*   **Computational Paradigms:** Approaches for modeling cognitive aspects of creativity, such as heuristic search, analogical reasoning, and cognitive architectures.
*   **Interdisciplinary Perspectives:** Drawing from philosophy, sociology, and other fields in the context of creative AI systems.
*   **Data and Creativity:** Data science approaches, resource development, and data gathering for creative AI.
*   **Societal Impact:** Ethical considerations, societal impact of computational creativity, and generative AI.
*   **Psychological Factors:** Computational models of psychological factors enhancing creativity (emotion, surprise, reflection, etc.).
*   **Provocations:** Raising new issues that question the foundations of the discipline.

*Note on generative AI models:* While welcomed, such models must be properly situated in the CC literature and evaluated according to field practices.

## Submission Instructions

The submission process has two stages:

1.  **Initial Submission:** Title and abstract (recommended length 100–200 words). Abstract can be updated with the full paper.
2.  **Full Paper Submission:** Submit the full paper.

*   **Paper Length:** Full papers: 8 pages + up to 2 pages of references.
*   **Review Process:** Double-blind review. Authors must ensure anonymity by removing identifying information (institution names, referring to past work in the third person, etc.).
*   **Formatting:** Submit as a PDF document using the ICCC style.
    *   LaTeX template: [here](https://computationalcreativity.net/ICCC-author-kit-2022.zip)
    *   Word template: [here](https://computationalcreativity.net/ICCC-author-kit-Word.zip)
*   **Submission Platform:** EasyChair system: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=iccc202501](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=iccc202501)
*   **Double Submissions Policy:** Work submitted to ICCC should not be under review elsewhere simultaneously.

## Camera-Ready Submission Instructions

Log into the EasyChair platform, select your paper, click “update file,” and upload the camera-ready version. Ensure compliance with length limits (8 pages + 2 reference pages) and formatting requirements.

## Student Grants

We are excited to announce a partnership with the Artificial Intelligence Journal (AIJ) for 10 grants covering the conference registration fee for selected students. This will allow them to attend the conference and associated events free of charge.

## Contact Us

*   Email: [iccc25@computationalcreativity.net](mailto:iccc25@computationalcreativity.net)
*   Follow us on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/iccc_conf), [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/iccc_conf/), or join our [Discord Server](https://computationalcreativity.net/iccc25/join-discord/).

# Call for Papers

Welcome to the 2025 ACM SIGPLAN International Symposium on Memory Management (ISMM 2025)! ISMM is the premier forum dedicated to research in memory management, covering a broad range of topics including memory performance, allocator design, garbage collection, architectural support for memory management, persistent memories, emerging memory technologies, and more. ISMM 2025 aims to encourage submissions and participation from related fields such as computer architecture and computer systems, in addition to the core PL community.

Update: Submissions are now due **2025-03-18 (AoE UTC-12h)**.

## Submission Types

ISMM 2025 is soliciting full-length submissions covering new work on all memory management related topics in both software and hardware (and their cooperation), as well as papers presenting confirmations or refutations of important prior results. In addition to regular papers, ISMM also invites submissions of the following kinds:

*   **Surveys and comparative analyses** that shed new light on previously published techniques.
*   **Practitioner reports**, describing experience with memory management in production. Such papers are not expected to provide novel research contributions, but they should not have been previously published.
*   **Intellectual abstracts**, where researchers share designs, algorithms, or theory that may be interesting to the memory management community, but not yet evaluated.

Please indicate the submission type using a subtitle, e.g., `\subtitle{This submission is a regular paper}`.

## Co-location

ISMM 2025 will be held in-person as part of PLDI 2025, sharing the venue and activities.

## Areas of Interest

Areas of interest include but are not limited to:

*   Garbage collection algorithms and implementations
*   Memory allocation and de-allocation
*   Memory system design and analysis (both software and hardware)
*   Hardware support for memory management
*   Memory management for large-scale data-intensive systems
*   Memory management at datacenter and cloud scales
*   Formal analysis and verification of memory management algorithms
*   Compiler analyses to aid memory management
*   Tools to analyze memory usage and characteristics of programs
*   Empirical analysis of memory intensive programs
*   Formal analysis and verification of memory intensive programs
*   Memory management for machine learning systems
*   Programming and management of emerging or persistent memories
*   Caches, memory controllers, memory hierarchies and their management
*   Cache coherence and memory consistency
*   Processing in memory (including processing near and using memory)
*   Memory technology and architecture (SRAM, DRAM, flash, NVM, emerging technologies)
*   Security and privacy of memory systems
*   Robustness of memory systems
*   Low-latency and low-energy memory systems

## Industry Participation

The symposium welcomes industry practitioners presenting their recent practice and findings in memory management related to real-world deployments.

## Submission Link

Submissions should be made via the hotcrp system: [https://ismm25.hotcrp.com](https://ismm25.hotcrp.com)

## Formatting Instructions

*   All papers must be submitted on-line in **Portable Document Format (PDF)**.
*   Papers should be formatted according to the **two-column ACM proceedings format**.
*   Each paper should have **no more than 12 pages**, excluding bibliography.
*   Font size should be **10pt**.
*   There is no limit on the page count for references.
*   Each reference must list all authors (do not use et al).
*   Citations should be in **numeric style**, e.g., `[52]`.
*   Submissions must be printable on US Letter and A4 sized paper.
*   Ensure figures and tables are legible, even when printed in grayscale.
*   Appendices should be submitted as supplementary material and must also be anonymized.
*   Use the `sigplan` subformat of the `acmart` format. The first two lines of the LaTeX document should be:
    ```latex
    \documentclass[sigplan,10pt,review,anonymous]{acmart}
    \settopmatter{printfolios=true,printccs=false,printacmref=false}
    ```

Papers that exceed the length requirement or deviate from the expected format will be rejected.

## Double-Blind Reviewing

ISMM uses double-blind reviewing. This means that author names and affiliations must be omitted from the submission. Additionally, references to prior work done by the authors should be made in the third person. Any supplementary material must also be anonymized. If you have doubts, please contact the Program Chairs.

## Declaring Conflicts

When submitting, you must declare potential conflicts, including adviser-advisee, institutional, financial, and recent co-authorship (last 2 years). Avoid spurious conflicts, as they can be grounds for rejection. Consult the Program Chair if unsure.

## Author Response

The author response process will occur in **April 2025**, providing an opportunity to respond to factual errors in reviews before final decisions are made.

## Important Dates (AoE - UTC-12h)

*   **Paper submission:** Tue 18 Mar 2025
*   **Author response period:** Wed 23 - Fri 25 Apr 2025
*   **Author notification:** Sat 3 May 2025
*   **Camera-ready papers due:** Thu 15 May 2025
*   **Conference day:** Tue 17 Jun 2025

# ISTAS 2025: Call for Papers

The IEEE International Symposium on Technology and Society (ISTAS) is the flagship conference of the IEEE’s Society on Social Implications of Technology (SSIT). ISTAS 2025 is a multi/inter/trans‐disciplinary forum for engineers, policymakers, entrepreneurs, philosophers, researchers, social scientists, technologists, and polymaths to collaborate, exchange experiences, and discuss the social implications of technology.

Hosted by the **Santa Clara University** (California, USA), ISTAS25 will be a **live hybrid conference** running from **September 10-12, 2025**, with live stream events as appropriate.

## Conference Theme: AI Evolution and Revolution

The ISTAS 2025 theme "AI Evolution and Revolution" focuses on the upheaval AI is causing in the world. SSIT invites participation from practitioners in academia, industry, and government who contemplate the future societal impact of AI, seeking to guide and manage this revolution to leverage benefits and minimize risks. The conference also invites individuals involved in technology policy and seeks to foster multidisciplinary, interdisciplinary, and trans-disciplinary interactions about legal, security, and economic issues of AI.

## Thematic Areas of Interest

*   **ETHICS AND GOVERNANCE**
    *   Ethical frameworks for AI development and deployment
    *   AI regulation, policy, and legal issues at national and international levels
    *   AI in Law Enforcement and Surveillance
    *   Transparency and explainability in AI systems
    *   AI privacy concerns
    *   Balancing innovation with responsible AI practices
    *   Human oversight and management
*   **HEALTHCARE AND BIOMEDICINE**
    *   AI-driven diagnostic tools and their impact on healthcare delivery
    *   Personalized medicine and AI
    *   AI in drug discovery and development
    *   Ethical considerations in AI-assisted medical decision-making
    *   AI’s role in addressing global health challenges
*   **FUTURE OF WORK AND INDUSTRY**
    *   Reskilling and education for an AI-driven economy and business climate
    *   Impact of AI on job markets and employment trends
    *   AI-human collaboration in the workplace
    *   AI in recruitment and human resources
    *   Governance and legal implications
    *   Economic implications of widespread AI adoption
    *   Infrastructure impact and change requirements
*   **ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY**
    *   AI applications in climate change modeling and mitigation
    *   Smart cities and AI-driven resource management
    *   AI in renewable energy optimization
    *   Environmental monitoring and conservation using AI
    *   Ethical considerations in using AI for environmental decision-making
    *   LLM/Data storage energy usage and design practices to mitigate
*   **CULTURE, ARTS, AND SOCIETY**
    *   AI’s impact on social interactions and relationships
    *   AI in education and learning
    *   AI-generated art, music, and literature
    *   AI and its effects on democracy and public discourse
    *   Cultural differences in AI perception and adoption
    *   AI, misinformation, and the public trust
    *   AI in Social Media

## Submission Types and Guidelines

All submissions must be uploaded to the ISTAS25 [EasyChair Submission Portal](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=istas25) in PDF format based on the IEEE conference template.

If you have not used EasyChair before, you will need to register before submitting your abstract, paper, or proposal.

### Special Sessions, Workshop, and Tutorial Proposals:

*   Submit a PDF of no more than 2 pages outlining a clear topic, objectives, and format, and explaining alignment with the conference theme/subtheme(s).
*   Provide a list of proposed presenters/facilitators or the plan for securing them.
*   Special Sessions typically involve a combination of presentations and audience dialogue; organizers must confirm at least three unique presenters by the submission deadline. Special session presenters are invited to submit papers for peer-review.

### Full-length papers:

*   **Length:** 6-8 pages (excluding references).
*   **Content:** Original, cutting-edge research with detailed methodology, comprehensive literature review, and clear explanation of novelty and contribution.
*   **Review:** Full peer-review for consideration in the ISTAS25 Proceedings (published on IEEE Xplore).

### Short Papers:

*   **Length:** 2-4 pages (excluding references).
*   **Content:** Preliminary findings, industry/practitioner/artist perspectives, or student research projects. Must present a clear central idea, relevant research/contexts, and references.

### Student Poster Abstracts:

*   **Length:** No longer than one page.
*   **Review:** Desk review from the student session committee.
*   **Publication:** Included in the conference program and website, but not the final proceedings.

## Important Dates

*   **Special Session Proposals Due:** ~~April 12, 2025~~ **May 16, 2025**
*   **Abstracts Due:** ~~May 2, 2025~~ **May 16, 2025**
*   **Full Papers Due:** ~~May 23, 2025~~ **August 1, 2025** (Note: Original input showed May 23, but later mentions Full Papers Due Aug 1. Assuming the later date is the final one for the purpose of CFP content.)
*   **Acceptance Notices:** ~~June 15, 2025~~ **July 18, 2025**
*   **Student Acceptance Notification:** July 14, 2025
*   **Student Confirmation of Acceptance & Conference Registration:** July 21, 2025
*   **Early Registration Deadline:** July 31, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Submissions Due:** ~~July 11, 2025~~ **August 1, 2025**
*   **Student Video/Final Poster or Slides Submission Deadline:** August 1, 2025
*   **ISTAS25 Conference:** September 10-12, 2025

## Paper Evaluation and Publication

All ISTAS25 submissions will be evaluated according to: Relevance, Validity, Significance/Originality, Methodological Basis and Rigor, and Balance, Structure, and Clarity.

The IEEE ISTAS25 proceedings will be published through the IEEE Xplore database. Papers will be included only if at least one author registers and pays the conference registration fee.

Select papers may be invited for expansion/revision and further peer review for a special issue of the IEEE Technology and Society Magazine.

## Contact Information

For questions about submission suitability, guidelines, or EasyChair procedures, please contact: [istas25@easychair.org](mailto:istas25@easychair.org).

## Formatting Resources

*   Visit the [IEEE Author Center](https://conferences.ieeeauthorcenter.ieee.org/) for guidance.
*   Additional author/presenter tips are available [here](https://conferences.ieeeauthorcenter.ieee.org/become-an-ieee-conference-author/).

## Registration Information

Early registration is open at discounted rates until **July 31, 2025**. Regular rates apply from August 1 to September 9. Special rates are available for IEEE and SSIT members, as well as Santa Clara University faculty and students. See the [ISTAS25 Registration Information page](https://attend.ieee.org/istas-2025/registration-information/) for details.

# IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW) 2025: Call for Papers

The 2025 IEEE Information Theory Workshop (ITW 2025) will be held from **September 29 – October 3, 2025, in Sydney, Australia**.

IEEE-ITW’25 solicits and welcomes original contributions on the frontiers of information theory, statistics, coding theory, and their applications, as well as interactions between information theory and other fields such as data science, biology, and signal processing.

## Conference Theme & Topics

ITW 2025 will put a specific focus on the areas of:

*   Information theory in Machine Learning
*   Quantum information and coding
*   Coding for 6G

# ISMB/ECCB 2025: Call for Submissions

The 33rd annual International Conference on Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology (ISMB), in conjunction with the 24th Annual Conference of the European Conference on Computational Biology (ECCB), will be the year's most important computational biology event. This international meeting will be held **in-person at the ACC Liverpool, UK**, and **virtually through ISCB's Nucleus platform**.

## About the Conference

ISMB/ECCB 2025 focuses on the development and application of advanced computational methods to address biological problems. It brings together researchers from computer science, bioinformatics, computational biology, molecular biology, mathematics, statistics, and related fields, providing a multidisciplinary platform for sharing the latest advancements and fostering new dialogues. # Call for Papers - KEOD 2025

The **International Conference on Knowledge Engineering and Ontology Development (KEOD) 2025** is a key event within the **17th International Joint Conference on Knowledge Discovery, Knowledge Engineering and Knowledge Management (IC3K)**. It will be held from **October 22-24, 2025**, with the venue located at the **Barceló Marbella hotel** in Marbella, Spain.

KEOD 2025 aims to bring together researchers and practitioners interested in methodologies and technologies related to Knowledge Engineering and Ontology Development, fostering dialogue and innovation across academic and industrial spheres.

## Hybrid Participation

Although the conference is returning to its normal in-person mode, speakers unable to travel to the venue are allowed to present remotely (hybrid support).

## Scope

**Knowledge Engineering (KE)** encompasses the technical, scientific, and social aspects of building, maintaining, and utilizing knowledge-based systems. It draws on AI, databases, expert systems, decision support systems, and software engineering, integrating insights from logic, cognitive science, and socio-cognitive engineering. Recent advancements, particularly in Large Language Models (LLMs) and Low-code/No-code Platforms, are expanding KE's reach by enabling automated ontology generation and greater accessibility.

**Ontology Development (OD)** focuses on creating reusable semantic structures like vocabularies, glossaries, and formal ontologies. These structures are essential in applications such as knowledge graphs, digital twins, explainable AI (XAI), cybersecurity, and IoT interoperability. Ontologies also play a crucial role in ensuring ethical AI development, mitigating bias, and enhancing transparency.

KEOD serves as a key venue for exploring traditional and cutting-edge topics like LLM-based Ontology Development, Ontology-driven Digital Twins, and Ontology-enhanced Low-code Platforms.

# IEEE International Test Conference (ITC) - Call for Contributions (TPTR'24)

## About the Workshop

"Top Picks in VLSI Test and Reliability” (TPTR) is a workshop that collects and presents the most impactful publications, keynotes, and invited presentations in the past 6 years in the areas of VLSI test and reliability.

For this year’s edition, the workshop is organized in two tracks:

1.  **Impactful Publications:** The most impactful publications from the past six years in the areas of VLSI test and reliability.
2.  **Impactful Keynotes/Invited Presentations:** The most impactful keynotes and invited presentations from the past six years, without an associated publication, in the same areas.

All articles in conferences and journals published from **2018 until the submission deadline** are eligible for track 1. Keynotes or invited talks from an IEEE TTTC-sponsored conference from **2018 until the submission deadline** are eligible for track 2. The two submission categories will be evaluated separately.

## Submission Process

*   **Submission Type:** TPTR accepts self-nominations by authors in the form of a **one-page letter**.
    *   The authors should summarize and highlight the key ideas and contributions of the presentation or publication.
    *   Describe the influence on ongoing research in the field.
    *   State the potential to positively impact the microelectronics industry in the long term.
*   **Review:** Submitted abstracts will be reviewed by a committee of renowned experts in the field and will be shortlisted.
*   **Presentation:** An author of each shortlisted publication must attend the workshop **in person** for a presentation showcasing its influence and impact. The presentation should be more than just replicating the original one. Authors should ensure that **30-40%** of the allocated time is dedicated to highlighting its influence on ongoing research in the field and its potential to impact the microelectronics industry.
*   **Final Selection:** The same committee (or a subset of it) will also attend the workshop to select a final list of Top Picks, which will then be invited for submission to an IEEE Design & Test special issue. The submission should not repeat or reword the original publication or presentation; it should be an extended version with new material.

# KR 2025: Call for Papers - Main Track

The 22nd International Conference on Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning (KR 2025) will be held from **November 11-17, 2025, in Melbourne, Australia**. The conference is co-located with CPAIOR 2025, ICAPS 2025, and NMR 2025.

## About KR

Knowledge Representation and Reasoning (KR) is a well-established and vibrant field of research within Artificial Intelligence. KR builds on the fundamental thesis that knowledge can often be represented in an explicit declarative form, suitable for processing by dedicated symbolic reasoning engines. KR has contributed to various areas of AI and beyond.

## Call for Papers: Main Track

We solicit papers presenting novel results on the principles of KR, which clearly contribute to the formal foundations of the field or show the applicability of KR techniques to implemented or implementable systems. We welcome papers from other areas that demonstrate clear use of, or contributions to, the principles or practice of KR. We also encourage "reports from the field" of applications, experiments, developments, and tests.

## Submission Guidelines for the Main Track

*   Submissions should be **anonymous** and will be subject to **double-blind peer review**.
*   Authors are encouraged to share and discuss their work as usual, including posting drafts online (e.g., on ArXiv).
*   Contributions may be **regular papers** (up to 9 pages) or **short papers** (up to 4 pages), including abstract, figures, and appendices (if any) but excluding references and acknowledgements.
*   Papers must be written in English and formatted using the [provided style files](files/KR25_authors_kit.zip).
*   The PDF file should be submitted through EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=kr2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=kr2025).
*   Authors of papers may submit a separate PDF or ZIP file with additional information supporting their claims (such as proof details, additional experimental results, further details on experimental design, etc).

## Important Dates (Main Track)

All deadlines are AoE - Anywhere on Earth (UTC-12).

*   **Submission of title and abstract:** May 7, 2025
*   **Paper submission deadline:** May 12, 2025
*   **Author response period:** June 25 - July 1, 2025
*   **Notification of acceptance:** July 10, 2025
*   **Camera-ready due:** August 15, 2025

## Publication

Accepted papers will be published in the KR 2025 proceedings. At least one author of each accepted paper is required to participate in the conference and present the work.

Top papers from KR 2025 will be invited to the award-winning paper tracks of Artificial Intelligence (AIJ) and the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research (JAIR).

# RecSys 2025: Call for Contributions

The 19th ACM Conference on Recommender Systems (RecSys 2025) will take place from **September 22 to 26, 2025**, in **Prague, Czech Republic**. RecSys is the premier international forum for presenting new research results, systems, and techniques in the field of recommender systems.

RecSys 2025 is committed to providing an inclusive, safe, and respectful conference environment for all attendees, adhering to the ACM Policy Against Discrimination and Harassment.

## In-Person Attendance Policy

RecSys 2025 is an **in-person conference**. Contributions to all tracks are expected to be presented in-person. At least one author from each accepted contribution must attend the conference in person to present their work and address audience questions. No pre-recorded videos will be permitted.

## Call for Full Papers

We invite high-impact original papers that contribute to all aspects of recommender systems. Submissions should be anonymous and adhere to the ACM 2-column template, limited to 8 pages (plus up to 2 pages for references).

*   **Abstract Due:** April 1, 2025
*   **Paper Due:** April 8, 2025
*   **Author Rebuttal:** May 20-26, 2025
*   **Notification:** July 3, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Due:** July 21, 2025

## Call for Short Papers

We welcome contributions that typically discuss exciting work that is not yet mature enough for the full paper track. Submissions are limited to 4 pages (plus up to 2 pages for references).

*   **Abstract Due:** April 22, 2025
*   **Paper Due:** April 30, 2025
*   **Author Rebuttal:** June 5-10, 2025
*   **Notification:** July 3, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Due:** July 21, 2025

## Call for Reproducibility Papers

We encourage submissions that replicate or analyze prior works, or contribute to an increased level of reproducibility. Submissions should be anonymous (except for Resource papers) and adhere to page limits for long or short papers.

*   **Paper Due:** May 13, 2025
*   **Author Rebuttal (Artifacts):** June 5-10, 2025
*   **Notification:** July 3, 2025

*   **Notification:** July 03, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Abstract Due:** July 21, 2025

*   **Submission Deadline:** May 15, 2025
*   **Notification:** July 3, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Due:** July 21, 2025

## Call for Tutorial Proposals

Proposals for tutorials covering established or emerging topics in recommender systems are invited. Proposals should include title, length, motivation, instructor details, detailed outline, target audience, and teaching experience.

*   **Proposal Due:** April 15, 2025
*   **Notification:** April 30, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Summary Due:** July 14, 2025

## Call for Workshop Proposals

Proposals for workshops on specialized topics or with novel interactive formats are welcome. The maximum length for proposals is 4 pages.

*   **Proposal Submission Deadline:** February 27, 2025
*   **Proposal Notification:** March 28, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Summary Due:** July 14, 2025

## Call for Demonstrations

Demos showcase implementations of novel recommender systems concepts or applications. Submissions should be anonymous and are a maximum of 2 pages (plus up to 1 page of references).

*   **Submission Deadline:** July 9, 2025
*   **Notifications:** August 4, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Paper Due:** August 11, 2025

## Call for Late-Breaking Results (LBR)

The LBR track is for presenting new, interesting, preliminary results, and speculative or innovative work in progress. Accepted contributions are presented as posters. The maximum length is 4 pages (plus up to 1 page of references).

*   **Submission Deadline:** July 9, 2025
*   **Notifications:** August 4, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Paper Due:** August 11, 2025

## Submission Guidelines & Formatting

*   **Submission Platform:** EasyChair (links will be provided per track).

*   **Plagiarism:** All submissions will be checked for plagiarism. Proper citation is required for any reused text.
*   **Ethical Review:** Compliance with ethical guidelines for human-subjects research is expected.
*   **Desk Rejection:** Submissions may be desk-rejected for violations of anonymity, length, formatting, dual submission policies, or academic dishonesty.

# Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing (PSB) 2026: Call for Papers, Abstracts and Demonstrations

The thirty-first Pacific Symposium on Biocomputing (PSB), will be held **January 3-7, 2026** at the **Fairmont Orchid on the Big Island of Hawaii**.

PSB will bring together top researchers from North America, the Asian Pacific nations, Europe and around the world to exchange research results and address open issues in all aspects of computational biology. PSB will provide a forum for the presentation of work in databases, algorithms, interfaces, visualization, modeling and other computational methods, as applied to biological problems, with emphasis on applications in data-rich areas of molecular biology. PSB intends to attract a balanced combination of computer scientists and biologists to present significant original research, demonstrate computer systems, and facilitate formal and informal discussions on topics of importance to computational biology.

## PSB 2026 Sessions

To provide focus for the very broad area of biological computing, PSB is organized into a series of specific sessions. Each session will involve both formal research presentations and open discussion groups.

*   **AI and Machine Learning in Clinical Medicine: Bridging or Separating Model Intelligence and Human Expertise**

    *   Session Chairs: Jason McDermott, Yana Bromberg, Hannah Carter, Travis Wheeler
    *   Contact: Jason McDermott, Jason.McDermott at pnnl.gov
*   **Fairness and Bias in Biomedical AI/ML: Defining Goals and Putting Them Into Practice**
    *   Session Chairs: Nicole Martinez-Martin, Mildred Cho
    *   Contact: Nicole Martinez-Martin, nicolemz at Stanford.edu
*   **Precision Medicine: Integrating large scale data and intermediate phenotypes for understanding health and treating disease**

# RECOMB 2025: Call for Papers

The RECOMB conference series, founded in 1997, provides a scientific forum for communicating advances in computational biology and its applications in molecular biology and medicine. RECOMB 2025 aims to bridge computational, mathematical, statistical, and biological sciences, bringing together researchers, professionals, students, and industrial practitioners.

## Topics

Papers reporting on original research (both theoretical and applied) in all areas of computational molecular biology are suitable for submission. Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   Molecular sequence analysis
*   Sequencing and genotyping technologies
*   Gene regulation and epigenomics
*   Transcriptomics
*   Single-cell omics
*   Metagenomics and microbiome analysis
*   Population genetics and statistical genomics
*   Evolution and comparative genomics
*   Structure and function of non-coding RNAs
*   Computational proteomics and proteogenomics
*   Computational structural biology
*   Computational metabolomics
*   Protein structure and function
*   Biological networks and network biology
*   Computational systems biology
*   Multimodal data integration in biological research
*   Computational approaches to understanding human disease
*   Data privacy and security in biomedical research
*   Bioimaging and molecular and cellular imaging analysis

## Submission Guidelines

*   Submissions should represent original, previously unpublished work.
*   Selected papers will be accepted for presentation at the conference.
*   Accepted abstracts will be published as a proceedings volume in the **Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics (LNBI)** series from Springer-Verlag.
*   Authors who prefer not to publish their papers in the LNBI proceedings must submit a final **four-page extended abstract** for inclusion in the Springer LNBI proceedings in lieu of the full paper. They must also submit the full paper to preprint servers (arxiv.org or bioRxiv.org) by the camera-ready deadline.

## Submission Deadlines

*   **Abstract/paper registration deadline:** October 16, 2024, 11:59 PM AoE
*   **Full paper submission deadline:** October 25, 2024, 11:59 PM AoE

*Note: All papers MUST be submitted, at least in abstract form, by the first submission deadline. No new submissions will be allowed after this date. Only those that have submitted by the first submission deadline will have the chance to update their submissions until the full paper submission deadline.*

## Paper Submission

Please submit your papers through EasyChair: [https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=recomb2025](https://easychair.org/conferences/?conf=recomb2025)

## Abstract Registration

*   A mandatory abstract submission deadline is on **October 16, 2024, 11:59 PM AoE**.
*   This deadline allows the Program Committee to begin planning review assignments.
*   After the abstract submission deadline, new submissions will not be accepted, but authors can update the full paper submission before the full paper deadline.
*   Ensure the abstract registration closely aligns with the full paper submission in terms of title, author list, and abstract content. "Placeholder" abstract registrations without meaningful descriptions will not be accepted.

## Formatting Instructions

*   **Main paper format:** All paper submissions must be in **PDF format**. The maximum length is **10 Letter pages**, including all figures/tables and their captions. Use a minimum font size of 10pt and 1-inch margins.
*   An additional title page containing the paper title, author list, and abstract is permitted.
*   The bibliography does not count toward the page limit.
*   Submissions that violate formatting requirements or exceed the page limit may be rejected without review.
*   Authors are encouraged to use the Springer Lecture Notes in Computer Science template [available here](https://www.springer.com/gp/computer-science/lncs/conference-proceedings-guidelines).

## Optional Appendix

*   An Appendix can be submitted as Supplementary Material in a single PDF file.
*   The Appendix should contain materials directly supporting the paper content.
*   There is no page limit for the Appendix, but reviewing it is at the discretion of the reviewers.

## Source Code Availability

*   If the paper involves new software or analysis methods, the source code should be made publicly accessible via a GitHub repository.
*   The link to this repository must be clearly indicated in the paper.

## Journal Publication

RECOMB is partnering with **Cell Systems**, **Genome Research**, and the **Journal of Computational Biology**.

Authors of selected accepted papers will be invited to submit a revised version for a special issue in one of the partnering journals. These journals will require some expansion of the REMB accepted papers.

Preprint server submissions are allowed without restrictions.

If a paper is submitted elsewhere in parallel, or intended to be submitted in parallel, it must be withdrawn from the full publication in the proceedings immediately upon acceptance, and the author must opt for the extended abstract option along with the mandatory preprint server submission.

## Contact

Please email Sriram Sankararaman, Program Committee Chair of RECOMB 2025, at [sriram@cs.ucla.edu](mailto:sriram@cs.ucla.edu) for any questions related to submissions.

General inquiries can be directed to [recomb2025@gmail.com](mailto:recomb2025@gmail.com).

# Call for Papers - RTSS 2025

The 46th IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS 2025) will take place in **Boston, MA, USA, from December 2–5, 2025**.

## Scope of the Conference

The IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS) is the premier conference in the field of real-time systems, where researchers and practitioners showcase innovations covering all aspects of real-time systems, including theory, design, analysis, implementation, verification, evaluation, and experience.

RTSS’25, the 46th edition of the event, continues the tradition of embracing new and emerging areas of real-time systems research.

## Timing Requirements

To be in scope, **ALL submissions must explicitly address some form of real-time requirements / constraints**. Examples include deadlines, response-time bounds, thresholds on acceptable tail latencies, as well as statistical and stochastic notions of timeliness.

Submissions should provide a compelling justification if the problem requires nontrivial resource allocation, programming, scheduling, or design approach to satisfy timing-predictability requirements. Improving average-case performance without regard to other criteria is not considered addressing a real-time requirement, unless it simultaneously ensures worst-case latency or execution time variability is not worsened.

RTSS especially welcomes new and emerging topics such as machine learning techniques for real-time systems, system design for real-time machine learning, resource management in autonomous systems, and system-level solutions for real-time applications exploiting domain-specific accelerators.

## Surveys and User Studies

Empirical survey-based research focused on the real-time systems field is also welcome. This includes surveys, questionnaires, interviews, use-cases, or other empirical techniques to obtain information about the state of research, design, development, verification, validation, and deployment of real-time systems.

Literature surveys that solely classify, review, and summarize existing research papers are not considered empirical research and are not in scope.

## Proceedings and Awards

All accepted papers will appear in the main program and proceedings, provided they are presented at the conference. A selection of papers will receive recognition as outstanding papers. **Best paper**, **best student paper**, and **best presentation awards** will be presented at the conference. Submissions are eligible for the best student paper award if the first author is a student as of the submission deadline.

## Tracks

RTSS’25 welcomes submissions of high-quality, original research papers related to both real-time systems theory and practice. Manuscripts may be submitted to either:

### Track 1: Real-Time Systems and Foundations

This track focuses on the practical and theoretical foundations that enable predictable timing in computing systems.

*   **Core real-time operating systems components** (kernels, hypervisors, middleware, runtime environments)
*   **Schedulability analysis and scheduling algorithms**
*   **Theoretical foundations of real-time systems**
*   **Verification methods**
*   **Timing analysis** (WCET analysis, measurement-based timing analysis)
*   **Real-time and time-sensitive networking**
*   **Timing-predictable hardware architectures**
*   **Modeling and analysis of stochastic real-time systems**
*   **Rigorous statistical and empirical approaches to timing predictability**
*   **Fault tolerance and security in relation to timing guarantees** (e.g., timing-based side-channel attacks, secure communication)
*   **Cross-layer timing predictability**
*   **Compiler techniques, system synthesis, model-driven engineering**
*   **Applied formal methods** (model checking, proof-based verification)
*   **Experimental system designs, case studies, and experience reports**
*   **Artificial Intelligence (AI) for Real-Time Systems Foundations**: Use of machine learning and other AI techniques to advance real-time scheduling, timing analysis, resource management, and system optimization under timing constraints.

### Track 2: Design and Applications

This track focuses on real-time systems in a broader systems context, emphasizing novel research on designs, implementations, and applications.

*   **Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS)**:
    *   Safety-critical, autonomous, and robotic systems.
    *   Enabling technologies and application-specific solutions for CPS.
    *   Theoretical foundations, design methodologies, simulation and emulation techniques, tool chains, CPS architectures.
    *   Secure CPS and CPS for security, performance analysis and robustness, safety and certification, hardware/software co-design.
*   **Real-Time System Design for Artificial Intelligence**:
    *   Practical implementation and integration of AI components (perception, planning, decision-making) in latency-sensitive and resource-constrained environments.
    *   System design, frameworks, resource management, hardware acceleration, and case studies for real-time AI deployment.
    *   AI safety in CPS, verification and validation of learning-enabled components, runtime monitoring, safe exploration, explainability, and robustness.
*   **HW-SW Integration and System-Level Design**:
    *   Design methodologies and tools for hardware/software integration and co-design.
    *   Architecture description languages, hardware architectures, design space exploration, synthesis, and optimization.
    *   System-on-Chip (SoC) design for real-time workloads (functional units, memory hierarchies, multi-core architectures, communication infrastructure).
    *   FPGA-based simulation and prototyping, software simulation and compilation for emerging architectures.
    *   Analysis of power, thermal behavior, timing, and predictability.
    *   Emerging trends: RISC-V platforms, AI/ML hardware accelerators, chiplet-based design.
*   **Internet of Things (IoT)**:
    *   Addressing resource constraints (energy, storage, computation), scalability, dynamic environments.
    *   Enabling real-time capabilities in IoT applications (distributed sensing and control, reliable communication, low-latency processing).
    *   Edge computing, fog computing, and AI-at-the-edge for real-time responsiveness.
    *   Application domains: smart cities, industrial IoT, smart healthcare.
    *   Emerging areas: 5G/6G for URLLC, in-network computing and offloading under timing constraints.

## Important Dates

*   **Submission Deadline (firm):** May 22, 2025 (anywhere on Earth)
*   **Author Response Period:** July 14-17, 2025
*   **Author Notification:** July 25, 2025
*   **Camera-Ready Deadline:** September 16, 2025 (tentative)
*   **Conference:** December 2–5, 2025

## Paper Submission

Authors are invited to submit supplemental research artifacts such as source code, mechanized proofs, data sets, formal models, short demo videos, etc., alongside their manuscripts. The paper submission form on HotCRP provides the opportunity to upload supplemental materials (up to 600 MB, as a ZIP archive).

Authors should use the official option to provide supplemental materials rather than linking to external repositories. Please refer to the href="./paper-submission/index.html" - paper submission guidelines for further details.

## Policy on Remote Participation

RTSS’25 is an in-person conference. Exceptions for authors unable to attend in person due to valid reasons (e.g., visa issues) will be made on a case-by-case basis at the discretion of the Program Chair. Authors requiring such exceptions should contact the Program Chair prior to paper submission. One author is required to register at the "in-person" rate (student or full) in any case.

## Hot Topics Day

A dedicated forum scheduled for December 2, 2025, to explore emerging research areas and developing trends in real-time and embedded systems. Proposals should be sent via email as a PDF to the Hot Topics Day Chair, Paolo Gai. The submission deadline for proposals is **July 15, 2025**.

# Call for Papers: SANER 2025

The 32nd IEEE International Conference on Software Analysis, Evolution, and Reengineering (SANER 2025) invites high-quality submissions of papers describing original and unpublished research results. SANER 2025 will be held from **March 04-07, 2025**, at **Polytechnique Montréal in Montreal, Canada**.

The conference promotes discussion and interaction among researchers and practitioners about the development of maintainable systems, and the improvement, evolution, migration, and reengineering of existing systems. SANER will feature technical research paper sessions, workshops, an early research achievements track, an industry paper track, a tool demonstration track, and a dedicated track on negative results in software analysis, evolution, and reengineering.

## Topics of Interest

Submissions should be of direct interest to the software analysis, evolution, and reengineering community. Topics of interest include, but are not limited to:

*   AI for Software Engineering
*   Software Engineering for AI
*   Generative AI and LLM
*   Software Tools for Software Evolution and Maintenance
*   Software Analysis, Parsing, and Fact Extraction
*   Software Reverse Engineering and Reengineering
*   Program Comprehension
*   Software Evolution Analysis
*   Software Architecture Recovery and Reverse Architecting
*   Program Transformation and Refactoring
*   Mining Software Repositories and Software Analytics
*   Software Visualization
*   Software Reconstruction and Migration
*   Software Maintenance and Evolution
*   Program Repair
*   Software Release Engineering, Continuous Integration, and Delivery
*   Empirical Studies on all the above topics
*   Education related to all of the above topics
*   Legal Aspects

We encourage submissions on collaborations between industry and academia, case studies, as well as experience reports relevant to the conference themes. Secondary studies synthesizing findings on these topics are also welcome, provided they offer a comprehensive synthesis.

## Submission Instructions

All submitted papers will undergo a rigorous peer review process and will be selected based on originality, quality, soundness, and relevance. Submissions must be original, not published, accepted, or under review elsewhere. All submissions must be in PDF format and conform to the IEEE Conference Proceedings Formatting Guidelines.

*   **Research Track:** Submissions should not exceed 12 pages (with the last 2 pages reserved for references only).
*   **Industrial Papers:** Submissions should not exceed 12 pages (with the last 2 pages reserved for references only) for full papers; talk proposals should not exceed 2 pages.
*   **Short Papers and Posters:** Submissions should not exceed 5 pages (including all text, figures, references, and appendices).
*   **Early Research Achievement (ERA) Track:** Submissions should not exceed 5 pages (including all text, figures, references, and appendices).
*   **Reproducibility Studies and Negative Results (RENE) Track:** Submissions should not exceed 4 pages for appendices to conference submissions or previous work and should not exceed 10 pages for new reproducibility studies and new descriptions of negative results.
*   **Tool Demo Track:** Submissions should not exceed 5 pages.
*   **Journal-First Papers Track:** Submissions should not exceed 1 page.
*   **Registered Report Track:** Submissions should not exceed 7 pages (with the last 1 page reserved for references only).

**Important Note:** Research, Short Papers, and Poster Tracks follow a full double-anonymous review process.

## Special Issue

Authors of selected research papers accepted at SANER 2025 will be invited to submit revised, extended versions of their manuscripts for a special issue featured by Springer’s Empirical Software Engineering Journal (EMSE). The best papers from the conference will be awarded.

The ACM SIGPLAN Symposium on Principles and Practice of Parallel Programming (PPoPP) 2025 will be held from **March 1st to March 5th, 2025**, at **The Westin Las Vegas Hotel & Spa in Las Vegas, Nevada, United States**.
